anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
how many games in a row have the uconn women's basketball team won
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["UConn is well-known for its men's and women's basketball teams, both of which are considered among the best programs in the country. The men's basketball teams have won four National Championships (1999, 2004, 2011 and 2014) while the women's basketball teams have won eleven National Championships (1995, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016) and have played in a total of 19 NCAA Final Fours, including nine in a row. The women's team went undefeated in the 1995, 2002, 2009, 2010, 2014 and 2016 seasons and ended a 111-game winning streak in the 2017 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament.\n", "The Connecticut Huskies are the team of the University of Connecticut (UConn); they play NCAA Division I sports. Both the men's basketball and women's basketball teams have won multiple national championships. In 2004, UConn became the first school in NCAA Division I history to have its men's and women's basketball programs win the national title in the same year; they repeated the feat in 2014 and are still the only school to win both titles in the same year. The UConn women's basketball team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at 111 games, a streak that ended in 2017. The UConn Huskies football team has played in the Football Bowl Subdivision since 2002, and has played in four bowl games.\n", "UConn women entered the 2010–11 season ranked No.\xa01 in all the national polls. On December 19, 2010, the UConn Huskies beat No.\xa010 ranked Ohio State at Madison Square Garden's annual Maggie Dixon Classic to tie the NCAA consecutive win streak to 88 games, and on December 21, 2010 they beat No.\xa020 ranked Florida State at the XL Center in Hartford to set a new NCAA consecutive win record at 89 games, the streak ended at 90 on December 30, 2010 with a 71–59 loss at Stanford.\n", "The team has been especially successful on its home court in the Harry A. Gampel Pavilion on the UConn campus in Storrs, Connecticut, and in the larger XL Center in Hartford; they tied an NCAA women's basketball record with 69 consecutive home wins between 2000 and 2003. That record was broken in 2011. The last home loss was to Villanova in the game that ended their 70-game winning streak. Moreover, between Auriemma's arrival and the close of the 2005 season, UConn won 295 games versus just 31 losses. The team set Big East Conference records for both single-game and season-long attendance.\n", "Women's basketball was not a major sport at UConn until the arrival of Auriemma in 1985. Under his guidance UConn has enjoyed unprecedented success, winning 11 national titles, including six at the end of undefeated seasons and four consecutive championships from 2013–16. The Huskies also have the two longest winning streaks in NCAA Division I basketball history, at 111 games from 2014–17 and 90 games from 2008–10. Connecticut's rivalry with women's basketball power Tennessee has been one of the most celebrated in the sport. Twenty-six former UConn women's basketball players have gone on to play in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), and five—Sue Bird in 2002, Diana Taurasi in 2004, Tina Charles in 2010, Maya Moore in 2011, and Breanna Stewart in 2016—have been selected first overall in the WNBA Draft. Stewart, Moriah Jefferson, and Morgan Tuck were the first three picks in the 2016 draft; this marked the first time three players from the same college were selected 1-2-3 in the draft of any major sport.\n", 'The Big East Tournament semi-final game was against Notre Dame, the third match up between the two teams this season. UConn won 59–44, to set a new NCAA women\'s basketball winning streak record at 71 games. However, the team was focused on upcoming games and "didn\'t even celebrate". UConn would go on to win the Big East title match against West Virginia 60–32.\n', "Competing in the American Athletic Conference as the Huskies, UConn has been particularly successful in their men's and women's basketball programs. The Huskies have won 21 NCAA championships. The UConn Huskies are the most successful women's basketball program in the nation, having won a record 11 NCAA Division I National Championships (tied with the UCLA Bruins men's basketball team) and a women's record four in a row (2013–2016), plus over 40 conference regular season and tournament championships. UConn also owns the two longest winning streaks of any gender in college basketball history.\n", "In June 2013, it was announced that the inaugural women's basketball tournament would take place at the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut. Women's basketball teams have played a total of 20 times in the NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Championship (since 1982), with UConn winning 11 national championships under head coach Geno Auriemma since 1995. Women's national championship tournaments prior to 1982 were run by the AIAW.\n", "While other #1 seeds Notre Dame, South Carolina and Baylor suffered early upsets in the NCAA Tournament, UConn easily advanced to the Final Four where they defeated Oregon State 80–51 and then old Big East rival Syracuse 82–51 in the Championship Game. UConn completed their sixth undefeated season winning the 11th overall Championship (all-time record for both men's and women's college basketball) and 4th in a row (also a record for women's college basketball). Geno Auriemma is now the only coach in college basketball to have won 11 titles, passing UCLA legend John Wooden (who has 10) and reaching former NBA coach Phil Jackson.\n", "The 2003 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament began on March 22, 2003, and concluded on April 8, 2003, when the Connecticut Huskies (UConn) won their second straight national title. The Final Four was held at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, Georgia on April 6–8, 2003. UConn, coached by Geno Auriemma, defeated archrival Tennessee, coached by Pat Summitt, 73–68 in the championship game. UConn's Diana Taurasi was named Most Outstanding Player.\n"]

**Expert Discussion on UConn Women's Basketball Winning Streaks**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The UConn women's basketball team has a storied history, particularly under the leadership of coach Geno Auriemma. They have achieved remarkable success, including an unprecedented 111-game winning streak from 2014 to 2017. This streak is not only the longest in women's college basketball history but also the longest in NCAA Division I basketball across both genders. The significance of this achievement cannot be overstated, as it showcases the team's dominance during that period.

**Expert 2: Statistical Analyst**
While the 111-game winning streak is indeed impressive, it's essential to contextualize it within the broader scope of UConn's performance. The team also had a 90-game winning streak from 2008 to 2010, which, while shorter, still highlights their consistent excellence. Additionally, UConn has had multiple seasons where they went undefeated, further emphasizing their ability to maintain high performance over extended periods. The statistical records indicate that UConn has not only set winning streaks but has also maintained a high level of competitiveness year after year.

**Expert 3: Cultural Impact Scholar**
The impact of UConn's winning streaks extends beyond just numbers; it has significantly influenced women's sports culture. The team's success has helped elevate women's basketball in the national consciousness, drawing attention to the sport and inspiring future generations of female athletes. The 111-game streak, in particular, served as a rallying point for discussions about gender equity in sports and the visibility of women's athletics.

**Expert 4: Rivalry and Competition Analyst**
While UConn's streaks are remarkable, it's important to consider the competitive landscape. The team's dominance has often overshadowed other programs, which can lead to a lack of parity in women's college basketball. Rivalries, such as the one with Tennessee, have historically been pivotal in shaping the narrative of women's basketball. Understanding these rivalries adds depth to the discussion of UConn's success, as they often faced formidable opponents that tested their mettle.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement:**
All experts agree on the significance of UConn's winning streaks, particularly the 111-game streak, as a hallmark of excellence in women's basketball. However, there is a divergence in focus: while some emphasize the historical and statistical achievements, others highlight the cultural implications and competitive dynamics. This disagreement enriches the discussion, as it encourages a multifaceted exploration of UConn's impact on the sport.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The UConn women's basketball team's winning streaks, particularly the record-setting 111-game streak, represent a pinnacle of achievement in NCAA Division I basketball. This success is not merely a reflection of athletic prowess but also a catalyst for cultural change in women's sports. The team's dominance has raised the profile of women's basketball, inspiring future athletes and contributing to ongoing discussions about equity in sports. Furthermore, the competitive context, including rivalries and the evolution of the sport, provides a deeper understanding of the challenges and triumphs faced by UConn.

In summary, the dialogue among experts reveals that UConn's winning streaks are significant not only for their numerical value but also for their broader implications in sports culture, competition, and the ongoing pursuit of gender equity in athletics.

Twenty-six former UConn women's basketball players have gone on to play in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), and five—Sue Bird in 2002, Diana Taurasi in 2004, Tina Charles in 2010, Maya Moore in 2011, and Breanna Stewart in 2016—have been selected first overall in the WNBA Draft. Stewart, Moriah Jefferson, and Morgan Tuck were the first three picks in the 2016 draft; this marked the first time three players from the same college were selected 1-2-3 in the draft of any major sport.
", 'The Big East Tournament semi-final game was against Notre Dame, the third match up between the two teams this season. UConn won 59–44, to set a new NCAA women's basketball winning streak record at 71 games. However, the team was focused on upcoming games and "didn't even celebrate". UConn would go on to win the Big East title match against West Virginia 60–32.
', "Competing in the American Athletic Conference as the Huskies, UConn has been particularly successful in their men's and women's basketball programs. The Huskies have won 21 NCAA championships. The UConn Huskies are the most successful women's basketball program in the nation, having won a record 11 NCAA Division I National Championships (tied with the UCLA Bruins men's basketball team) and a women's record four in a row (2013–2016), plus over 40 conference regular season and tournament championships. UConn also owns the two longest winning streaks of any gender in college basketball history.
", "In June 2013, it was announced that the inaugural women's basketball tournament would take place at the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut. Women's basketball teams have played a total of 20 times in the NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Championship (since 1982), with UConn winning 11 national championships under head coach Geno Auriemma since 1995. Women's national championship tournaments prior to 1982 were run by the AIAW.
", "While other #1 seeds Notre Dame, South Carolina and Baylor suffered early upsets in the NCAA Tournament, UConn easily advanced to the Final Four where they defeated Oregon State 80–51 and then old Big East rival Syracuse 82–51 in the Championship Game. UConn completed their sixth undefeated season winning the 11th overall Championship (all-time record for both men's and women's college basketball) and 4th in a row (also a record for women's college basketball). Geno Auriemma is now the only coach in college basketball to have won 11 titles, passing UCLA legend John Wooden (who has 10) and reaching former NBA coach Phil Jackson.
", "The 2003 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament began on March 22, 2003, and concluded on April 8, 2003, when the Connecticut Huskies (UConn) won their second straight national title. The Final Four was held at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, Georgia on April 6–8, 2003. UConn, coached by Geno Auriemma, defeated archrival Tennessee, coached by Pat Summitt, 73–68 in the championship game. UConn's Diana Taurasi was named Most Outstanding Player.
"]

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages about the UConn women's basketball team's winning streaks and achievements. Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Winning Streaks**:
   - UConn women's basketball team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at **111 games**, which ended in 2017.
   - They also had a previous winning streak of **90 games** from 2008 to 2010.
   - The team set a new NCAA women's basketball winning streak record at **71 games** during the Big East Tournament.

2. **National Championships**:
   - UConn women's basketball has won **11 National Championships** (1995, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016).
   - They achieved **four consecutive championships** from 2013 to 2016.

3. **Undefeated Seasons**:
   - The women's team went undefeated in several seasons: **1995, 2002, 2009, 2010, 2014, and 2016**.

4. **Coaching and Program Success**:
   - The success of the UConn women's basketball program is attributed to head coach **Geno Auriemma**, who has led the team to unprecedented achievements since his arrival in 1985.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The information about winning streaks and championships allows the model to understand the causal relationship between consistent performance (winning streaks) and overall success (national championships). For example, the model can infer that a longer winning streak likely contributes to a higher probability of winning championships.

2. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - The chronological order of events (e.g., streaks leading to championships) helps the model develop temporal reasoning skills. It can learn to associate specific time frames with outcomes, such as how consecutive wins correlate with championship victories.

3. **Pattern Recognition**:
   - By analyzing the patterns of winning streaks and undefeated seasons, the model can improve its ability to recognize and predict outcomes based on historical data. For instance, if a team has a long winning streak, it may be more likely to succeed in upcoming tournaments.

4. **Contextual Inference**:
   - The context of UConn's success under a specific coach provides a framework for the model to infer that leadership and coaching strategies can significantly impact a team's performance. This can be generalized to other sports or contexts where leadership plays a crucial role.

5. **Comparative Analysis**:
   - The mention of UConn's records in relation to other teams (e.g., the only school to win both men's and women's titles in the same year) allows the model to engage in comparative reasoning, enhancing its ability to evaluate performance across different entities.

By consolidating this information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to make more informed predictions and analyses based on historical data and established patterns in sports performance.
